Mathematical and Bitwise Operators

These operate exactly like their counterparts for the built-in integer types.

Note that there is no operator~. Since the integer type doesn't have a fixed maximum size, there is no logical way to implement it.

bool operator! () const
integer & operator%= (const integer &b)
integer & operator&= (const integer &n)

Static Public Member Functions

Preconstructed integers

These return preconstructed integers with the values named by the functions. They are used internally, so that the most common values don't have to be constructed each time they're needed.

static const integer & one ()
static const integer & zero ()

Detailed Description

The core integer class.

This class implements the standard integer type.

There are only a few member functions; most of the functionality is implemented using standalone functions.

boost::xint::integer::integer ( const integer &  b  ) 

Creates a copy of an existing integer.

Parameters:
[in] b An existing integer.
Note:
This library can use a copy-on-write technique, making copying (even of large numbers) a very inexpensive operation.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

Definition at line 64 of file integer.cpp.

boost::xint::integer::integer ( const std::string &  str,
size_t  base = 10 
) [explicit]

Create an integer from a string representation.

  • Complexity: O(n2)
Parameters:
[in] str A string representation of a number.
[in] base The base of the number, or xint::autobase.
Exceptions:
exceptions::invalid_base if the base parameter is not between 2 and 36 (inclusive) or the constant xint::autobase.
exceptions::invalid_digit if the string contains any digit that cannot be part of a number in the specified base, or if there are no valid digits.
Remarks:
This will convert a string representation of a number into an integer. See the description of the from_string function for details on its behavior.
This is the most common way to initialize values that are too large to fit into a native integral type.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

) [inline]

Constructs a new integer object with the value of the built-in signed integer passed to it.

Parameters:
[in] n A number of type T.
Template Parameters:
T The type of n.

You can ignore the enable_if parameters, they are there only to tell the compiler what types it applies to.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

Tests the lowest bit of *this to determine evenness.

  • Complexity: O(1)

Tells you roughly how large *this is.

  • Complexity: O(1)
Returns:
The number of hexadecimal digits that would be required to encode this.

Definition at line 172 of file integer.cpp.

int boost::xint::integer::sign ( bool  signed_zero = false  )  const

Tests the sign of *this.

  • Complexity: O(1)
Parameters:
[in] signed_zero If false (the default value), returns zero if *this is zero. If true, returns 1 or -1 on a zero *this as well. Primarily used to identify a negative zero.
Returns:
-1 if *this is negative, 0 if it's zero, or 1 if it's greater than zero.
